title: 109_hr5388
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Fair and Equal House Voting Rights Act of 2006" aims to provide voting representation for over half a million residents of the District of Columbia in the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives. District residents have a history of defending democracy and pay significant federal taxes, aligning with the principles of "one person, one vote" and "government by the consent of the governed." The District of Columbia is considered a Congressional district for representation in the House of Representatives, with limitations on the number of Members it can receive under reapportionment. The text discusses amendments related to the determination of presidential electors based on the 23rd amendment and conforming amendments regarding appointments to service academies in the District of Columbia. Amendments are made to the United States Naval Academy and the United States Air Force Academy by striking certain paragraphs and references to the District of Columbia. These changes apply to the One Hundred Tenth Congress and each succeeding Congress. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN MEMBERSHIP OF HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. The House of Representatives will have 437 members starting from the One Hundred Tenth Congress. Reapportionment of members will be based on this new number. The President must transmit a revised statement of apportionment to Congress within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, and the Clerk must report on it within 15 days. The Clerk of the House of Representatives sends a certificate to each State with the number of Representatives they are entitled to. A report is submitted to the Speaker identifying the State entitled to an additional Representative. Requirements for election of additional member are outlined for a specific period. After the 2010 census, reapportionment occurs. The State identified for an additional Representative will elect them at large, while other Representatives will be elected based on existing Congressional districts. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF OFFICE OF DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DELEGATE. The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, restoring laws as if the act had not been enacted. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to replace references to "Delegate to Congress" with "Representative in the Congress." The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, and references to "Delegate to Congress" are replaced with "Representative in the Congress" in various sections of the D.C. Official Code. The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, and references to "Delegate to Congress" are replaced with "Representative in the Congress" in various sections of the D.C. Official Code, including amendments to subsections and sections related to vacancies in the office of Representative in Congress. The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, and references to "Delegate to Congress" are replaced with "Representative in the Congress" in various sections of the D.C. Official Code, effective for elections from 2006 onwards. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF OFFICE OF STATEHOOD REPRESENTATIVE. Amendment to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979 to change references from "Representative" to "Senator" and remove mentions of the Representative position in various subsections. Amendment to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979 includes changes to the Statehood commission and authorization of appropriations. Amendments are made to various laws in the District of Columbia, including limitations on honoraria, application of campaign finance laws, and changes to the District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955. These changes involve removing references to "United States Representative" in different sections of the laws. Amendments to the District of Columbia laws involve removing references to "United States Representative" in different sections. Effective in 2006 and subsequent years. SEC. 7. NONSEVERABILITY OF PROVISIONS: If any provision of this Act or its amendments is held invalid, the remaining provisions will also be considered invalid.
